chapter.htmlHeader: How should I diagnose the cause of nipple pain?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Following a full assessment of the woman and infant, diagnose the underlying cause of nipple pain, where possible.

  • Physiological milk let-down pain
    • There is often pain for the first few minutes of breastfeeding, which resolves with continuation of the feed.
    • Pain often improves during the first few weeks of breastfeeding.
  • Nipple damage
    • Inefficient positioning and attachment typically causes nipple pain at the start of a breastfeed which continues throughout the feed.
    • Pressure from suckling may cause blanching and compression of the nipple, and fissuring across the top of the nipple or around the base.
    • There may be flattening of the nipple from side to side, with a pressure line across the tip.
  • Blocked duct
    • There may be a small white spot (bleb) about 1 mm in diameter at the end of the nipple. 
    • There may be a localized, tender cord of tissue in one breast, which may be relieved by expression of milk; the overlying skin may be erythematous.
  • Nipple infection
    • Bacterial infection may present with purulent nipple discharge, crusting, redness, and fissuring. See the CKS topic on Impetigo for more information.
    • Candida infection typically causes bilateral burning nipple pain, itching, and hypersensitivity of the nipple, especially during and soon after feeds. There may be deep breast pain radiating into the breast and chest wall (ductal infection pain). The nipple may be red, shiny, swollen, or fissured. Typically the pain does not resolve despite improved positioning and attachment, or follows a period of pain-free breastfeeding. See the CKS topic on Candida - skin for more information.
  • Skin conditions
    • Eczema and psoriasis of the areola and nipple may cause itching of the skin. Eczema typically causes a bilateral red, dry, scaly rash which may have lichenified (thickened) areas, which tend to spare the base of the nipple. Psoriasis typically causes red plaques with clearly demarcated borders, which may have a fine overlying scale. See the CKS topics on Eczema - atopic, Dermatitis - contact, and Psoriasis for more information.
    • Paget's disease of the nipple may mimic eczema, but is usually unilateral, persistent, and unresponsive to treatment for eczema. In addition, there may be skin ulceration or erosions. See the CKS topic on Breast cancer - recognition and referral for more information.
  • Nipple vasospasm or Raynaud's disease of the nipple
    • Nipple pain is typically intermittent, and present during and immediately after breastfeeds, and in between feeds if exposed to cold temperatures.
    • Blanching of the nipple may be followed by cyanosis and/or erythema.
    • Nipple pain resolves when the nipple returns to its normal colour.
    • There may be a personal or family history of Raynaud's phenomenon of the digits. See the CKS topic on Raynaud's phenomenon for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on how to diagnose the cause of nipple pain are based on the World Health Organization (WHO) publication Infant and young child feeding - model chapter for textbooks [WHO, 2009], the US Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine clinical protocol Persistent pain with breastfeeding [Berens et al, 2016], a retrospective case review of Raynaud's phenomenon of the nipple [Barrett et al, 2013], expert opinion in review articles on breastfeeding problems [Amir, 2014; Amir, 2016], and expert opinion in a Statement by the National Infant Feeding Network Thrush [National Infant Feeding Network, 2014a].
